text: I'm really looking forward to sharing some great content with you all actually the goal of today's webinar is to give
you some really practical information around partnering we're going to move fast because I want to give you as much
as I can in the limited time we have and I've been driving partner marketing for a while now as well as Channel
development and it never gets old and these are all tools that I myself actually use so when we look at the
agenda for today we're going to talk about Frameworks for thinking of partner relationships going to give you a few
tools for structuring success and then give you a guide that I actually use to
put it all in action with my teams and now my team at twio actually so let's
start off with some Frameworks for thinking about partnering relationships but we should probably take one little
step back which is to talk about why do you partner now that seems pretty obvious to most folks oh yeah you got to
have Partners right well there's some very specific reasons and benefits around having partners so let's go
through a few of those first of all companies will partner to enable Focus there are things that you really want to
put your talent and your resources on and there are other things that are just stuff you have to get done so if you can
find a partner can get that stuff done so you can focus on what you do really well can be a huge benefit to the
company people partnered a reduce costs uh that can be across any line of things
from manufacturing to services to just delivering a great product so reducing costs that a great reason to partner
people partner for Market access often times a company will be able to get in by market we mean both Geographic
markets and also vertical markets they'll be able to get into one market very easily but not know how to
penetrate another region or vertical or area of the world and they'll use Partners to be able to get that access
we partner for customer access sometimes you'll have a great offering something that you really want to move to Market
but you can't get to those customers you really want to get to and a partner can help you with that we partner to
complete the solution we may not have all the pieces ourselves and I've had this happen to me and a number of
companies um over time and so you'll partner to find other people who can help you complete the solution we're
going to talk about that idea a little bit more in depth we partner for Innovation and differentiation I see a
lot of companies that will have this great product that they have offered out there they'll have a great service out
there but they don't have that Innovation capability inside and they'll find Partners who can actually do it
oftentimes and I've actually seen a couple of customers uh do this is that they may actually then acquire that
company in the end for that ability to be able to continue that Innovation and differentiation we partner to expand
sources of revenue there may be offerings that someone else has that could really complement the portfolio of
what you're already offering and by bringing those into your portfolio and leveraging your sales team you can
actually create new sources of revenue we partner to expand resource access you see this a lot in industrial companies
where they need to have natural resource access and I'm sure there are other reasons as well why people partner but
important to think about all the benefits that partnering could actually bring to you so let's jump to our first
framework and that's really looking at how you might segment the different types of Partners you're working with to
really keep this simple I boil it down to three buckets first bucket is supplier Partners second bucket is
distribution Partners third bucket is influence partners and we'll talk a little bit about each of these so first
of all supplier Partners probably pretty obvious the Strategic question you have to ask yourself is am I going to buy it
or am I going to build it and the role of that supplier partner then becomes to complete the solution which we just
spoke to enabling a faster time to Market facilitating focus on the core
competencies that a company has giving a competitive Advantage uh and reducing costs all things we just spoke to
distribution Partners key question you have to ask yourself here is do I want to go indirectly to the market or
directly to the market and the role of a distribution partner then is to extend that sales reach accelerate sales and
reduce costs and then our third bucket which is one that people often forget about to think about really as partners
when they're thinking about this full portfolio approach are influence Partners strategic
question there is am I better to go together with someone else into the market or should I do it alone the role
there is influence Partners can provide brand leverage extend Market reach and they can afford some cost sh uh sharing
in the process so let's dig a little deeper into each one of these the first one is that idea of the supplier partner
and a tool that I have always found effective in looking at who are all the partners that I might need to bring my
full product to Market is something we call the whole product the whole product is that minimum set of products and
complimentary services that are needed to fulfill on that value proposition that compelling reason to buy when
you're going into the marketplace and I actually will create this uh circle map and lay out the different pieces that I
need when I am looking at the whole product and bringing uh into the market now one of the areas that people often
forget about when they're thinking about suppliers is the services side most custom customers whether it's a consumer
or a busino business environment they have expectations of getting this very complete solution inclusive of all the
services and services can actually be a great differentiator around a product so really think carefully about the whole
product and in addition to just the product components you might need what are the services that you're also going
to need and are there partners that would be more effective in helping you deliver that coming now to our question of do I
need a distribution partner one of the things here and again a tool that I have found useful is thinking about what is
my distribution strategy but thinking of it in the context of high touch and low
touch so if you have an offering in the market which is really easy to Market and understand and the solution that
you're delivering the product you're delivering the offering you're delivering isn't that complicated to deploy you can go into a low Touch model
and therefore you can look for partners that offer that low touch environment it may be someone that has a website that
can be able to that can distribute your product as well or your service offering through the website it may be a retail
store where there's not a lot of involvement from the sales folks if on the other hand what you're bringing to
Market has super high complexity in terms of making people understand it or understand some element like the pricing
plan mobile phones are a great example of this you think a mobile phone is easy to buy but that pricing plan makes it actually really complex to understand or
the solution complexity um is very high in terms of actually getting something
up and running then you're going to want to more have a more hight Touch model and look for partners that can offer
that someone that has a true sales force that can go in and sit down uh with a customer so when you're thinking about
your distribution Partners think about your distribution strategy think about it in the context of low touch and high
touch that'll help you get a good feeling for what type of partners are actually going to be feasible for you to
work with and then the third bucket that we had on our list are the influence partners and as I said these are the
ones that often get forgotten um because they don't think of them really as partners but when you're looking at total portfolio Management in a partner
Arrangement you want to make sure that these folks get factored in so let's talk about different type of influence
Partners there are marketing Partners these are folks that you go to market with and you get great brand association
with them you can do some demand creation you see a lot of this we're in Holiday times you see a lot of this during holiday times where two totally
different companies maybe it's wine and chocolate come together to be able to bring something to Market and it really
is about a marketing partnership you'll see side by-side selling Partners these are folks that hey they're going into an
account you have something that their account might like there's some value that you can bring together and they bring you in and work with you but again
there's no passing of money there's no supplier type relationship distribution type of relationship it's just going in
and selling side by side Association Partners can be really super interesting
drawing on my path actually before Tech started off in the Aerospace industry we had something called the helicopter
Association International everyone in the helicopter industry belonged to it that group affiliation of being able to
get together in a common place and time read the same Publications really helped
develop the offering that we had in the market there ecosystem Partners their
value is really that idea of network effect I think a great example here is when you think about uh mobile phones
and that huge system of folks that they have around from the people that make the cases to the people who make the
apps there's a whole Network effect that is created by an ecosystem of Partners
and then and you see this a lot overseas there is the idea of government partners partners who really endorse the business
of what you're doing so important to also think about influence Partners so kind of first framework we have here is
thinking about the different types of Partners and how you might segment that portfolio of Partners you're going to
have to manage all right we're going to now move on to another framework that I like
which is really think thinking about what is that role of the partner and some Partners Focus are focused on more
than just the profit you might get from the relationship so the way this framework is really set up is to look at
what is the revenue and profit Potential from the partner versus what are the core competencies they might help you to
deliver so Partnerships can be more than just about money they can be about making you a better company and so I
will look at the partners that I'm working with and kind of look at where do they fit in terms of this framework
so let's start with kind of the easy ones so if someone has low Revenue potential for you or low profit
potential and they're also not going to do much to help you develop your core competencies call that a limited partner
you should probably limit how much you do with that partner as well because they're probably not going to bring you a lot of value the other Corner
strategic partner again pretty easy to look at revenue and profit potential is high they can really help you develop
your core competencies this is a really important partner as a part of your portfolio and then looking at the other
two quadrants if a partner is great at helping you drive Revenue but maybe not
as helpful to you in terms of developing your core competencies we would call that an earning partner and then in the
lower bottom corner there Learning Partner these are folks that may not help you drive a lot of Revenue or
profit but actually they're going to help you develop your core competencies as a business so another framework in
thinking about partner relationships is to think about is this about the money is this about the core competencies that
I might be able to develop through this relationship what's the Right Mix helps you think about the role that this
partner really helps you play now this has been a very much an inside what I
call an inside out discussion what does it mean to me what's the value to me as a company it's also really important to
think about partnering relationships from an outside in perspective what this means is what's the value back to them
and I actually ran into this situation where I had a core component technology
uh was great technology it was a sexy technology everyone wanted to talk about it we relied on Partners as distribution
Partners In this case they were all out there creating the buzz which obviously had some value to us because it helped
us spread word of mouth and get the word out about what the company was doing but what we found out in the process when
our revenues weren't going up the way we thought they should for all the distribution Partners we had we really
dug in to understand the value from an outside in perspective and what we found out was we were really to talk about but
in the end the productivity from a revenue perspective for those distribution Partners just wasn't that
high they had other things in their toolbox that they wanted to sell stuff that was going to retire sales quotas a
lot faster and what we found was that we were in the position of being an orphan product super hot and sexy to talk about
but not really that thing at the end of the day that the partner was out there selling so another way to think about
Partners is from an outside in perspective and to understand from the partner perspective am I a mainstream
prodct that they're going to be out there selling they're out talking about that they're going to want to build great things around because they see it
as good revenue for them am I a product that is somewhat adjacent or contiguous
to what that partner is doing so interesting um but not rocket ship stuff am I an unworthy product meaning there
just no relationship at all that we should be having or am I an orphan product someone that's kind of sexy to
talk about but not going to drive a lot of Revenue so important thought here is always look at relationships from an
inside out perspective but also take that outside in perspective as
well all right so few Frameworks to think about uh partnering thinking about
why am I partnering first framework we looked at was looking at what was going
on in terms of our partner portfolio segmentation we had that opportunity to talk about what roles do these Partners
really play for us and then talked about that inside out and outside in perspective of is this a partnership
that's going to be successful so now I want to share with you some tools for structuring success and again these are
tools that I have actually used in practice so one of the hardest parts
about managing a partner portfolio for success is how do you distribute the
resources and I've always found that there seem to be always more mouths to feed than budget resources to actually
give out and another thing that's really hard in all this is saying No in fact for me that's one of the toughest thing
about strategy in general is it's harder to say no than yes and so making the tough decisions of where you're going to
align those resources becomes really key so going to give you three tools uh for working with that and thinking about
resource alignment so this first one looks at that question of value again
value to the partner and value to the company and then looking at where you
actually apply uh the resource now what I've actually done is taken this and I've actually mapped out where my

make sure I'm in alignment with my colleagues on how we should be addressing a giving partner relationship
so again we'll start with the easy ones if it's there's low value to the partner and low value to your company then you
probably have a misfit here and shouldn't be spending any time or resources around this partner you may be
sitting oh yeah that's actually very obvious but the reality is it does happen and if you dig into your own
partner portfolio you're probably going to be surprised to find that there are actually some companies there that hey
nice people they contacted us at a trade show or an event we wanted to do some business with them but there was really
never a good fit for the relationship so don't put any resources there the other
one that's super easy is the Strategic partner bucket these are ones where there's a high value to the partner there's a high value to your company and
this is where the bulk of your resources should be going in term terms of investment in the partner relationships
and now going to our other two corners if there is a high value to the partner but not as much value to your company
this is probably an opportunistic relationship you're going to put some money in it you're going to put some people time into it but at the end of
the day you're probably going to get that partner company to put in more resources than you would to the relationship because it's more important
to them Flip Side Lower box back to our orphan status if it's high value to your
company but maybe not as high value to that other company that you're working with then you will probably be the one
that puts more resources into it than that partner does so good tool for
thinking about resource alignment thinking about where your Partnerships fall and then making sure that everyone
in your company has the same perspective because you will end up where other departments are contributing to the
partner relationship and you want to make sure that everyone's in Balance so going to jump to our next
tool um this one again same kind of a four boox setup but instead of looking at it
from a value perspective of value to the partner and value to you as an individual this tool has you look at it
from a perspective of strategic value of the relationship and the growth potential of that relationship Now

type of new products that you could innovate on together it could be in terms of the number of customers um that
you would be able to impact because of either the right product or the distribution but again thinking about

four boxes so if someone is high gross potential and high strategic value what
are the specific things that we're willing to do for them if someone is high strategic value but low growth
potential there's probably another set of logical things that we would do as a company around that partnering

in terms of managing that account relationship all right third tool in

we're looking at Partners as opportunistic partners ones that we not sure how far the relationships going to

thinking about what kind of resources and what kind of time am I willing to put into this partnership and then what

you're getting the right resources to the right Partners at the right
time okay super critical I didn't know about this quite frankly till um
probably about 10 years ago but there's a different type of proposition for
partners than there is for customers kind of used to always think ah it's a value proposition that all apply to
everyone and what you really start learning when you dig into it is that partners are very different and there is
this construct of the partner business proposition and this business proposition answers a very simple
question for the partner why should we BET our resources and reputation on you
this contrasts with the traditional value proposition that you've probably encountered in marketing which is why
should I buy your product the reason this is so important is if you can't articulate why a partner should be
betting their resources on you chances are that it's not going to be a strong partnership it might even fit into that
Misfit bucket that we've talked about so let's compare the two so when we think
about contrasting the propositions a value proposition is all focused on the product that you've got it's all focused
on the objective of selling products using that value proposition and it's generally built out out by looking at
what are the features we offer and then what are the benefits that they return to our customers when you're looking to
write the business proposition for Partnerships it's focused obviously on the partners and it's about creating a
bias towards you through that business proposition so the partner looks at it and goes well there's no way we couldn't
partner this is this is something we have to go do and the attributes of it rather than being features and benefits
are more aligned to things like profit incremental sales strategic value the
things that are going to get that partner jazzed about working with you now one of the things that I like to do
is before I actually go in and meet a partner and start discussing how we're going to work together is really think

tool for making that partnership successful all right this is an oldie b

relationship be sure your partner understands the value you bring to the relationship they may just think it's

successful and that takes the whole organization rallying around the fact that they've got partners that are

we're so used to social networks at the end of the day business is still about people and find a good reason to partner

and evolve and part of a partnering relationship is being there for each other and then focus on his added value
at the end of the day so just some things some best practices some ways to think about how to make those
Partnerships successful and then a last tool partnering life cycle what you see over
on the left is the stage of the life cycle on the right the general description of it and Partnerships are a
lot like personal relationships they grow and they change over time understanding where your partners fit
from a life cycle perspective is important because you're going to do some things differently you're going to treat the relationship potentially
differently and interestingly you will find every partnership going through the same type of a life cycle you have the
early phase the dating phase partners are sizing each other up firms are mobilizing internal support for the
alliance there's a lot of energy about how are we're going to get this together how are we going to make it successful
and you also really see a lot of attention to it and so people on their game then you get into that growth phase
that hey we got this thing going you want to make sure that it's continuing forward but you have to demonstrate
commitment to it because it's really easy especially if you're building up multiple Partnerships to go for the shiny object oh let's go put all that
energy into the new uh partnership make sure you invest in that growth phase and you understand that you're in the growth
phase and then there is a maturity phase there is that kind of oh well we've been together for a while you know should we
still be doing this is this still the right marriage to be a part of and it's about really revisiting that
relationship understanding the value contracts may be up for renegotiation deciding whether this is still the right
relationship are you still in it because you've been in it for a long time go back and look at your partnering
relationships think about where they actually sit in each phases of these life cycles and think about are you
treating it all the same or are you actually treating each phase of the life cycle slightly differently because you
will find you will have a more successful relationship if you commit to this idea of there is a life cycle
behind the relationships we're working in so those are some tools for structuring Success there are a ton more
